answers.answer: I dont think that sounds too big?? im not sure why she wants to go straight to a csection without trying vaginal first? and why is she talking about it so early? if anything why not induce you at 39 weeks if she is concerned about the size... but even that would be strange? i dono what think about this at all??

I want to know why there is an increased risk of still birth? i hope someone else can give their insight on this... this is very concerning that your Dr is pushing a c section?And i have to add that i plan on a Vbac this round so im not against c sections but if they are not necessary then why get one?
sorry thats not supposed to say vbac thats supposed to say second csection... i honestly dont see a vbac working for me

I had a 35 week u/s with my first child and it estimated her weight to be over 7lbs.  She was a big baby, 9-3 but I did end up having a c-section.  The questions you are asking, you should be asking your doctor.  Only she will be able to give you the reasons behind her suggestions.  I don't know much about gestational diabetes but I do know women who have had it and delivered naturally.  I would obviously try to go that route and if you have to ask another ob for an opinion then do it.  It would be better for your piece of mind.  Six pounds at 37 weeks is pretty average.

question: Ok well I will start off by saying I am 38 weeks pregnant with my first child and have gestational diabetes. My ob wants me to gave a scheduled c-section. She says that there is a higher chance of still birth and complications if I go naturaly or the baby grows to big. My baby according to ultrasound at 37 weeks weighs 6 pounds 10 ounces. Which to me does not seem large at all. I am 3 cm dialated and have 2 weeks left untill due date. I would rather wait to see if he will come on his own and try giving birth vaginaly before just deciding on a c-section.  Is a c-section nessasary just because I have gd?
title: concerned about c-section
